## Problem 1 (Easy): 

Use the `Macbeth_raw` data from the `mdsr` package to answer the following questions:

a. Find all of the adjectives in Macbeth that end in more or less


```{r}
data(Macbeth_raw)
glimpse(Macbeth_raw)
macbeth <- Macbeth_raw %>%
  str_split("\r\n") %>% # specify the end-of-line character(s)
  pluck(1) # str_split returns a list of length 1
# we grab its first element
length(macbeth)
view(macbeth)

macbeth %>% 
  str_subset("[a-z]less|[a-z]more") %>% 
length()


```


b. Find all of the lines containing the stage direction Exit or Exeunt.

```{r}
macbeth %>% 
  str_subset("Exit|Exeunt") %>% 
length()
```

## Problem 2 (Medium): 

a. Use regular expressions to determine the number of speaking lines in the Complete Works of William Shakespeare. Here, we care only about how many times a character speaksâ€”not what they say or for how long they
speak.

```{r}
shakespeare_url <- "https://www.gutenberg.org/files/100/100-0.txt"
shakespeare <- RCurl::getURL(shakespeare_url)
shakespeare2 <- shakespeare %>%
  str_split("\r\n") %>% # specify the end-of-line character(s)
  pluck(1) # str_split returns a list of length 1
# we grab its first element
view(shakespeare2)
length(shakespeare2)
```
